articles.headline: Disney to Lose Special Tax Status in Florida Amid ‘Don’t Say Gay’ Clash
articles.snippet: Lawmakers in the state voted to revoke the company’s special designation after a dispute with Gov. Ron DeSantis over a new education law.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers in the state voted to revoke the company’s special designation after a dispute with Gov. Ron DeSantis over a new education law.
articles.lead_paragraph: Disney employs 38 lobbyists in Florida’s capital. Each election cycle, the company gives generous campaign contributions to Florida candidates on both sides of the political aisle. Its theme park megaresort near Orlando attracts around 50 million visitors a year, powering a Central Florida tourism economy that annually generates more than $5 billion in local and state tax revenue.

articles.headline: Next Phase of War Will Be Pivotal for Russia and Ukraine, U.S. Says
articles.snippet: Reflecting a renewed sense of urgency, President Biden announced that the United States would send the Ukrainians $800 million more in military aid.
articles.abstract: Reflecting a renewed sense of urgency, President Biden announced that the United States would send the Ukrainians $800 million more in military aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senior Biden administration officials say they believe that the next four weeks will shape the eventual outcome of Russia’s war in Ukraine, with long-lasting ramifications that will influence the drawing of the map of Europe for decades to come.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Calling Off Steel Plant Assault, Putin Prematurely Claims Victory in Mariupol
articles.snippet: With casualties mounting and progress slow in his war on Ukraine, Vladimir V. Putin is eager to present it to the Russian people as a success.
articles.abstract: With casualties mounting and progress slow in his war on Ukraine, Vladimir V. Putin is eager to present it to the Russian people as a success.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia claimed victory in Mariupol on Thursday despite persistent fighting there, publicly calling off an assault on the final Ukrainian stronghold in the devastated city in a stark display of the Kremlin’s desire to present a success to the Russian public.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski, Ivan Nechepurenko and Richard Pérez-Peña

articles.headline: Should a Morning Staff Meeting Feel Like Homeroom?
articles.lead_paragraph: Hybrid-work arrangements often sound like math equations. Three days a week in the office, two at home; 50 workers commuting into an office of 10,000 square feet and 10 pizzas. It all adds up to 40 hours, somehow — and a logistical challenge for businesses trying to determine whether one part of the solution is keeping track of people’s comings and goings.
articles.byline: By Emma Goldberg and Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: E.U. Takes Aim at Social Media’s Harms With Landmark New Law
articles.snippet: The Digital Services Act would force Meta, Google and others to combat misinformation and restrict certain online ads. How European officials will wield it remains to be seen.
articles.abstract: The Digital Services Act would force Meta, Google and others to combat misinformation and restrict certain online ads. How European officials will wield it remains to be seen.
articles.lead_paragraph: The European Union reached a deal on Saturday on landmark legislation that would force Facebook, YouTube and other internet services to combat misinformation, disclose how their services amplify divisive content and stop targeting online ads based on a person’s ethnicity, religion or sexual orientation.

articles.headline: As Europe Approves New Tech Laws, the U.S. Falls Further Behind
articles.snippet: Federal privacy bills, security legislation and antitrust laws to address the power of the tech giants have all failed to advance in Congress, despite hand wringing and shows of bipartisan support.
articles.abstract: Federal privacy bills, security legislation and antitrust laws to address the power of the tech giants have all failed to advance in Congress, despite hand wringing and shows of bipartisan support.
articles.lead_paragraph: In just the last few years, Europe has seen a sweeping law for online privacy take effect, approved far-reaching regulations to curb the dominance of the tech giants and on Saturday reached a deal on new legislation to protect its citizens from harmful online content.

articles.headline: In Polarized Texas, Rare Accord: A Hispanic Mother Shouldn’t Be Executed
articles.snippet: The execution of Melissa Lucio would be the first of a Hispanic woman in Texas. New evidence casts doubt on her conviction.
articles.abstract: The execution of Melissa Lucio would be the first of a Hispanic woman in Texas. New evidence casts doubt on her conviction.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — In less than a week, Texas is set to execute Melissa Lucio, a mother of 14 who was convicted of murder in the death of her 2-year-old daughter more than a decade ago.

articles.headline: A Look Inside the Textbooks That Florida Rejected
articles.snippet: The state rejected dozens of math textbooks. The New York Times reviewed 21 of them to figure out why.
articles.abstract: The state rejected dozens of math textbooks. The New York Times reviewed 21 of them to figure out why.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Dana Goldstein and Stephanie Saul

articles.headline: Jeffrey Epstein, a Rare Cello and an Enduring Mystery
articles.snippet: A cello’s strange odyssey helps explain how the notorious Mr. Epstein surrounded himself with the world’s richest and most powerful men.
articles.abstract: A cello’s strange odyssey helps explain how the notorious Mr. Epstein surrounded himself with the world’s richest and most powerful men.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Jeffrey Epstein died in jail in 2019, he took many secrets with him. One was how a sexual predator and college dropout managed to forge bonds with an astonishing number of the world’s richest and most powerful men, like Britain’s Prince Andrew and the crown prince of Saudi Arabia.

articles.headline: McCarthy Said Trump Acknowledged ‘Some Responsibility’ for Jan. 6
articles.snippet: New audio captures what Representative Kevin McCarthy said to Republicans shortly after the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
articles.abstract: New audio captures what Representative Kevin McCarthy said to Republicans shortly after the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
articles.lead_paragraph: Representative Kevin McCarthy, the House Republican leader, told G.O.P. lawmakers in the days after the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol that former President Donald J. Trump acknowledged he bore “some responsibility” for what happened that day, new audio revealed on Friday.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin, Alexander Burns and Neil Vigdor
